citations.narrative:
On January 14, 2023, photographs were posted on social media of guests petting Lucifer, a male juvenile jaguar (DOB
approximately 3/28/22) and Betty, a female juvenile Syrian Brown Bear (DOB estimated at no later than 3/1/22), who are
both over 16 weeks of age. Lucifer arrived at the facility on 5/2/22 as a 5-week-old. Betty arrived 3/28/22 with no age
listed but a weight of 6.5#. Lucifer would have been 16 weeks of age on approximately 7/18/22 while Betty would have
reached 16 weeks before 6/21/22. Facility representatives stated that public petting of the juvenile bear and jaguar
hadn’t taken place since about 12/25/22, but both animals would have still been too large and strong and over 7 & 8
months of age.
Handling of dangerous animals such as jaguars and bears over the age of 16 weeks poses a risk of injury to the public,
and maintaining control is questionable even while leashed or distracted by a bottle. Animals of this size are too big, too
fast and too strong to be used for public contact. During public exhibition, dangerous animals such as lions, tigers,
wolves, bears, or jaguars must be handled by trained facility personnel in such a manner so that there is minimal risk of
harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and general viewing
public so as to assure the safety of both the animals and the public.
To be corrected from this day forward,
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
End Section

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On January 14, 2023, photographs were posted on social media of guests petting Lucifer, a male juvenile jaguar (DOB 
approximately 3/28/22) and Betty, a female juvenile Syrian Brown Bear (DOB estimated at no later than 3/1/22), who are 
both over 16 weeks of age. Lucifer arrived at the facility on 5/2/22 as a 5-week-old.  Betty arrived 3/28/22 with no age 
listed but a weight of 6.5#.  Lucifer would have been 16 weeks of age on approximately 7/18/22 while Betty would have 
reached 16 weeks before 6/21/22.   Facility representatives stated that public petting of the juvenile bear and jaguar 
hadn’t taken place since about 12/25/22, but both animals would have still been too large and strong and over 7 & 8 
months of age. 
 Handling of dangerous animals such as jaguars and bears over the age of 16 weeks poses a risk of injury to the public, 
and maintaining control is questionable even while leashed or distracted by a bottle. Animals of this size are too big, too 
fast and too strong to be used for public contact.  During public exhibition, dangerous animals such as lions, tigers, 
wolves, bears, or jaguars must be handled by trained facility personnel in such a manner so that there is minimal risk of 
harm to the animal and to the public, with sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and general viewing 
public so as to assure the safety of both the animals and the public. 
To be corrected from this day forward,

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee. 
 
End Section

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
